dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILL, 40s, sorts through piles of industrial hardware and cable. When he finds several pieces of metal grate, he se them aside. His daughter, TOM, young teens, works with hi

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: We only need one more. She hands him one she’s found. They leave a small payment for the man who lives in the lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom and Will enter a dense park by scrambling up a gully, avoiding the public entrance. They're in Forest Park, a temperate rain forest abutting city of Portland, Oregon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not using an established path, they walk over fallen tree and bushes. Tom stops. She holds back some brambles. On the ground is dead animal. She picks up a stick and examines the body.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: How many organs can you identify? Tom peers through under growth to an animal’s body.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: That’s his liver. Lungs. Heart.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (pointing with the stick) I’m not sure what that is.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Spleen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Someone probably hit him with their car. He came too close to town. They walk away into the woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They arrive at a spot where they toss down their packs. They're home. Will lights a lantern which emits a low lig He pulls back some large branches which they’ve used to obscure their dwelling, constructed with a tent and tarps In front of it, they’ve set up a small cooking area. A camping stove is perched on a flat rock and two tree stum stools are arranged around a small table fashioned from a board. Will stashes their groceries in a buried food cooling cac Tom lights a lamp. He processes wood - splitting it with his knife. Tom feathers the tinder sticks. Will ignites the tinder with the ferro rod They sit together and eat their soup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will is reading. Tom arranges her sleeping bag.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Need a second layer?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I’m fine. She gets in and comfortable. He turns out the light.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See you in the a.m. They make their private clicking communication sound. After a moment, they hear the sound of snapping branches some dogs run through the brush and through their camp. O dog stops to sniff around their tent. Will switches on a flashlight and they can see the outline of its snout protruding through the shelter wall. Will reaches for a p and bangs it with a spoon, which sends the dog away.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I named the head dog Layla.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: If she’s such a good friend of yours, you could tell her that we're trying to get some sleep around here.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I don’t speak dog. Will smiles.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Let’s try to get back to sleep. He settles in attempting to fall asleep again, but is wid awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom walks along a fallen tree to a small garden covered b transparent plastic tarp. She pulls back the tarp and wee As she works, she gets distracted by pill bugs and centip under a log. She uses a magnifier to look closely at the centipede. With the knife on her belt, she cuts deeper in the log and reveals more bugs. EXT. FOREST PARK — DAY 7 Tom forages in the forest for edible plants. She uses a s pair of field glasses to identify a bird she hears. She pokes around a fallen tree and discovers the yellow t of a chanterelle mushroom hidden underneath.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yes! She investigates further and finds a small patch of the mushrooms and begins snapping them off at the base. In th distance, she can hear her father make a a bird sound. Tom answers him with an owl sound. She gathers the mushrooms, puts them in the pocket of her hoodie and heads back to camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She cuts through some low brush to get to Will. He's immersed in building a solar cooker, using the scrap meta they collected as a base.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Look what I found. He glances up to look at the mushrooms, but he’s absorbed what he’s constructing.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Excellent. Good haul. Give me a hand here? She holds pieces of foil while Will tacks them in place o the frame of an umbrella. She looks at the book he’s using to learn about solar cooking.  10

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Do you think we’ll ever be able to cook on this? It seems better for a sunny state.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: There’s radiant energy even when you can’t see the sun.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Maybe so, but I couldn’t wait 2 weeks for an egg. He’s in thought about improvements.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This’ll be good in summer.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m hungry. Can we finish this later?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Yes. He smiles at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will, in his city clothes, conservative neutral colored garments, combs his beard. He clicks to get her attention

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Code Brown. After a moment, Tom comes from behind the privacy tarp, dressed in her clothes for town. She washes her hands. .

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Clean your nails. He passes her a sharpened stick. She notices a long pine needle in his clothing and picks it off. He tidies up their dwell space and she coves the lids of cache buckets. They check each others’ clothing and do one last preening EXT. FOREST PARK — DAY 10 Tom and Will walk parallel to each other through the tree At one point, Will stops, crouches down, and looks back f where they’ve come to see if their path can be detected.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: We've been this way one time too Many. New route needed. They continue on.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It’s only Tuesday. Why are we going to town today?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Schedules and routines are fine, but you don’t want to be predictable. That’s when you get hit, by being overconfident. (pause) Anyway, we're low on food -- milk powder, oatmeal. Your appetite is growing.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I'm growing!

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I know.  11 12 13 Al3 14 15 She smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they approach the boundary of where the park meets pav streets, Tom and Will exit using one of the public paths stairs, looking like any other folk leaving the park. Tom spots a necklace on the ground. She picks it up, looks at and puts it back on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: If it’s still here when we get back, can I take it?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Yep. That’s fair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will and Tom quickly scramble down a steep gully in Fores Park. They check each others’ appearance, brushing off bits of forest debris, from clothing, hair, and beard. They walk in the direction of the St. John’s Bridge. EXT. ST. JOHN’S BRIDGE - DAY 13 They walk across the bridge to get into town. EXT. ST JOHN’S SQ. - DAY Al3 They deposit two small bags of garbage into the dumpster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom looks at the city; Will looks at the enormous medical complex looming in front of them. There are a few other passengers. TWO MEDICAL WORKERS in white coats are in the mix. As they approach, The VA hospital takes up the whole view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom is in the waiting room reading. Her book obscures her face. She glances up at the glass passageways of this labyrinth.  6aA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will meets back up with Tom. He stows the meds package th he’s been given at the clinic into his back pack.  17

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will withdraws money from an ATM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shop efficiently for the essentials. Will puts a chocolate bar in the cart, and Tom is surprised.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Is that a want or a need?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Both. She seems pleased. EXT. ST. JOHN’S BRIDGE - DAY Al18 Tom and Will cross the bridge, carrying a tote with their groceries EXT. FOREST PARK, MEN’S CAMP —- DAY 19 Tom and Will approach an encampment in a different sectio the park, comprised of several tents. One has an American flag hanging off the front and a wheelchair beside it. One of the men living in the camp, LARRY, a vet who knows Will from the VA, greets them. Larry opens the package of pill bottles, tearing off the warning labels that are aff to the bottles and the suicide literature that the VA pac in every bundle. Two of the bottles are smaller than the others.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: They've changed the cocktail again. Larry checks the label on the small bottles.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Less Roxi’s, less bars. Figures, they're cuttin’ back on the ones that have any value to us. He checks the big bottles.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Looks like someone’s tryin’ to unload the sleep meds -- Seroquel, it really has no value to me. I'd have to find someone who wants to sleep all day and gain 70 pounds. (rifling through the bag Prazosin - when’s the last time that stopped a nightmare? They must be gettin’ a deal on these.  Will nods. Larry takes all the bottles and pays Will.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: They’re harder to get.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: First, they give ‘em out like candy, and now they’re yankin’ the leash back. Will makes a small parting gesture.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whatever they’re givin’ you, I'll take ‘em off your hands. He looks over at Tom.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom and Will walk away from the men’s camp up a curving p into the trees.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It’s weird, going there.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: If you’re going to say something, be specific.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It makes me feel sad to be there.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: That makes sense.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Then why do we go?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: We don’t need the meds, but we can use the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will clears the air shaft for the dakota pit. He maintain the water catchment system.  22 23 EXT. FOREST PARK — DAY 22 Tom ventures into a part of the forest that is far from t camp and closer to the public hiking paths. In the trees can see the orange vests of an inmate WORK CREW. AN OFFIC walks back and forth supervising. Tom spies from behind t trees. She moves closer, staying in the shadows. The worker closest to sees Tom through the branches and stares. They lock eyes for a minute. Tom steps back and hurries away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will’s working on a fire, but the dampness makes it hard start. Tom chops the mushrooms. She’s hungry and the fire taking a long time.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: This is all so wet.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Can we use the propane?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Heard your stomach growl. He nods that propane is the way to go in this instance.  24 25 10 She turns on the propane camp stove and the mushrooms coo quickly. She gives Will one to taste. They enjoy. Will now hears the sound of the power tools from the work crew in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I saw them earlier, it’s OK, it’s a work crew. They’re way down by the pathways.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Drill. She pops the last of the mushroom into her mouth. He shut down the stove, moving quickly fueled by adrenalin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hustles Tom along to their emergency hiding area. Will watches her hide in the foliage of a large fern. He check from all angles to see if she’s truly covered, but she’s slightly visible.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: The pattern of the face is the first thing someone can recognize. She pulls herself deeper into the fern.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Dad, I know how to do this. Her hiding is not precise enough.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Then be good at it. He covers himself in the foliage in a way that makes him imperceptible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom relaxes in her hiding spot, which she uses as a look- She's reading the section on sea horses in the encycloped  26 27 11 From below, the sound of cracking sticks can be heard, an soon the huffing and puffing of a man. An off-trail RUNNE comes into the clearing. He stops and puts his hands on h knees, spitting on the ground. As Tom scoots farther back on the hiding spot to be out o his sight, she knocks a book off. The runner doesn’t see book fall, but hears it and turns around, craning his nec see if he can spot someone. Tom contracts into a small ba

dialogues.speaker: RUNNER
dialogues.text: Hello? Somebody up there? He steps back a few paces trying to see more, catching a glimpse of her.

dialogues.speaker: RUNNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello? Tom holds her breath. She remains utterly still waiting u she can hear him resume his run and leave the area. She peers over the edge to confirm that he’s gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, back on the ground moves quietly in the direction wh the runner took off to check that he’s no longer in sight It hits her that an outsider has seen her. She sits for a moment to collect herself. At the base of the log she’s sitting on, she finds an odd looking mushroom, which she picks and heads home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Tom approaches their camp, she finds Will looking at t Forest Park map. She sits near him, still shaken from the runner encounter. When he looks up, she hands him the wei mushroom to examine. Tom looks through the Wild Edible Mushroom Guide and trie match it to one of the photos.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Fairy ring mushroom --no ink cap, hexagonal-pored polypore, common puffball, Avenging Angel... She stops on the next page and double checks the mushroom against the photo. TOM (CONT’D) I think I found it. The Prince!  28

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Double check that it has no deadly- poisonous lookalikes.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Check again. Tom sketches the mushroom in her mushroom and fungi and writes the number 21 on it.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We're up to 21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom is awakened by Will, who is having a nightmare. gently nudges her father.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Dad. Wake up. You were having a dream.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Whoa. Will takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What’s your favorite color?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: What’s yours?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yellow.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: The way it makes me feel. It’s bright and not still.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Mine’s green.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: That figures. And what was my mother’s favorite color?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Yellow. 12 notebook She 28

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Maybe she taught me that, for it to be my favorite.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: In some way.Let’s get some sleep; it’s late.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I wish I could remember her.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: She would’ve wished that, too. Good night, Yellow.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Good night, Green.  29 30 31 32 13

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chess game is in process.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Always try to control the 4 squares

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Food, clothing, shelter, fuel.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Yes. In front of your King and Queen. (he moves her king’s pawn up two squares forward) A lot of people think it looks dangerous to move the pawn in front of the King, but as long as you Castle, it will be safe for a while. It’s Tom’s move. They both hear unfamiliar distant sounds Will listens intently, detecting the muffled sounds of a walkie-talkie. Will and Tom look at each other, knowing t is not a drill. The sound gets louder. As Tom starts to s the chess pieces back in their box, Will grabs her arm an they run through the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom scrambles into hiding. Will, a couple feet away, also disappears. Then everything grows quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A K-9 OFFICER looks through their camp and picks up a pie of clothing to let the dog register the scent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A POLICE OFFICER scans the area. Peering out from her hiding spot, Tom can see a boot crus ferns around her. The K-9 officer arrives and lets the dog off the leash. After a moment, the dog discovers Will.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE
dialogues.text: Stand up. Will gets to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hands behind your head.  14 The officer pats him down and removes Will’s knife.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you have any ID?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Not on me. My military ID- it’s in my pack.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE
dialogues.text: Why were you running?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: We didn’t know who you were.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE
dialogues.text: Are you alone? Pause. Will has to make a decision. The K-9 officer feeds dog snacks from a pouch.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: My daughter’s with me. Tom, come out. Tom stands up and the officials turn to see her. She thro her small camping knife to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE
dialogues.text: (to Tom) Come on over here. Tom looks to her father. He nods that she should do what’ asked. JEAN, a social worker, is lead in by the RANGER. Will bac away slightly.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sir, we need you to stay where you are. Please stop moving around. I don’t wanna have to cuff you. Tom grabs her dad’s arm.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (trying to use a softer tone with Tom) Please, step aside.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (to the cop) We're not a threat -- you don’t have to act this way in front of her.  15

dialogues.speaker: POLICE
dialogues.text: We don’t know who you are or what the situation is here. Jean gently inserts herself between Tom and Will as the police officer leads Will away, with the ranger following Tom looks past Jean to keep Will in her sight.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Dad! Will stops walking and the police have to tug at him. Tom tries to get around Jean to follow her father. Jean gentl stops her, but she pushes against her.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: PLEASE! I want to go where my dad goes.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: We'll figure this out. We’re gonna make sure you’re OK.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We're OK!

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: We're here to help.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We don’t need help.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Hey, I’m Jean. What is your name?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Tom. Why did you chase us?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: We need to know what’s going on here.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You needed a dog to figure that out?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: We couldn’t have found you otherwise. They walk off in the direction of the encampment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom and Jean approach the camp where Will  16 has been detained. Tom sees the runner waiting with the ranger. The runner glances in her direction, trying to se who she is. The K-9 officer has entered their living quarters.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: There are some library books to return. Green pack at the back. Will hears one of the book crates topple over, followed b dish crashing.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're not hiding anything from you. Jean leads Tom to sit down on a log. Tom keeps her eyes o her dad as the officer turns him around so Jean can talk privately to her.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You don’t have to worry. He’1ll be all right. We’re going to focus on you. The ranger checks out the camp, snapping photos of the stealth fire pit.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE
dialogues.text: You had no idea they had fire up here? The ranger shakes his head, intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You guys are pretty well set up. How long have you been here?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: A long time.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Can you tell me who you live with?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: My dad.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: It’s only the two of you?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Can you show me where you sleep? Tom brings her to the entrance of the shelter and shows h  16aA

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: My sleeping bag here. Dad’s there.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE
dialogues.text: Sir!  34 17 Tom and Jean look up to see that Will has walked up to th Both cops hold him back. The officers look at Jean, who nods OK to them. They rele Will a little, and he approaches Tom. He leans in and spe softly.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: We've got nothing to hide. It’s very important that we cooperate with them. Tom pushes forward and puts her arms around her father.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We'll be back together soon. He bends down to be on her eye level. The cop, carrying Will’s pack, and the K-9 unit lead Will away. The ranger and runner follow. Will turns back and smiles at Tom, who uses her sleeve to wipe her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jean waits for Tom. She gathers her journal, some books, clothes, stuffing them into her pack.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: When am I coming back?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I don’t think you will be.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Will somebody bring my encyclopedias?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: We'll see if we can have somebody come back for those. Jean realizes what she’s just said and how untrue it is.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Actually, pick two letters, take your two favorite letters for now.  35 18 Tom emerges from their dwelling with her pack and two vol of the encyclopedia.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Does your dad ever drink or take pills that make him act strange? Tom nods no.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Does your dad have any weapons here? Anything that could hurt someone? Tom nods no.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Or places where you’ve seen him hide things? Tom opens the buried cache bucket which contains papers i ziplock bag, a collection of utility knives and a small s Jean looks in. Tom retrieves the papers and then closes t lid and covers it back up. Tom arranges branches to camouflage the cache. Jean lets her finish covering the entrance with branches. They head away from the camp. Tom is nimble in this terra Prickers grab at Jean’s clothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exit Forest Park to where the Social Services van is parked, near a large park diagram. Tom looks around for W Jean opens the back door and gestures for Tom to get in. doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Where’s my dad?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: He’s on his way to our office to answer some questions. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And we need to ask you some too. You'll see him soon, but you’re going to have to be a little patient. I know this is hard.  36 19 Jean gestures again for her to get in. She does. She clos her door and gets into the driver's seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, in a medical gown, is being examined by a female DOC The doctor takes off a blood pressure cuff and puts the otoscope away. She enters data on Tom as she preforms the child wellness exam. She swipes her tablet.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: We're getting you into the system here -- Thomasin. Is that your preferred name and how you'd like us to refer to you?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I'd like for you to refer to me as Tom.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: I’m required by the state to ask: “How do you identify? Female? Male? Or Other?”

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Female. The doctor scrolls through more of the intake. She looks in Tom’s ears with an otoscope. Checks eyes wit medical eye pen, puts a blood pressure cuff on her arm.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: You are very healthy. Everything looks good.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Where are my things?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: We'll give you back your clothes very soon. We’re washing them and putting them in the bug oven.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Bug oven?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: That's a way of heating clothes to kill any body lice that may be in your clothing.  37 20

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I don’t have bugs living in my clothing.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: We do this for everyone who stays here. It’s a precaution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom walks into the dorm room. She sees two teenagers, TIF and VALERIE, sitting at the table making collages from magazines. She stands, not sure what to do.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: Are you just gonna stand there?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Can I sit down?

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: Whatever you wanna do. Tom sits down. She sees a plate of sandwiches on the tabl

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Can I have one of those sandwiches?

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: Knock yourself out, but not the cheese one, that’s mine. Tom takes a sandwich and eats. The girls keep cutting and pasting.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What are you guys doing?

dialogues.speaker: TIFFANY
dialogues.text: Making dream boards.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: Basically, you cut up magazines and then you make a board of what you want to do for the rest of your life. Things that could make you feel good about your future.

dialogues.speaker: TIFFANY
dialogues.text: Jean asks us to make them.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: [Tom may ask about Chanel detail on the board]

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: So, what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I’m here because I wasn’t where I was supposed to be, I guess. Well, they don’t think I was where I was supposed to be.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: Okay, so, where were you?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I was with my dad. In Forest Park.

dialogues.speaker: TIFFANY
dialogues.text: Forest Park?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: Like, the woods? Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: TIFFANY
dialogues.text: Was your dad taking care of you?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: But you were homeless, basically.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: Then why else would you be living in the woods?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Well, that was our home.

dialogues.speaker: TIFFANY
dialogues.text: If you had a home they wouldn’t have brought you here.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Well, they just don’t understand that that was our home.

dialogues.speaker: TIFFANY
dialogues.text: And where is your dad now?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: He’s somewhere in this building, I think, but he’s gonna come and get me in a couple hours, I think.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: Your dad’s gonna come back and get you?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yeah. Why wouldn’t he? That’s what Jean said. They’re just sorting it out.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: You know, just so you know, most of the kids that come in here, their dads don’t come back for them. Tiffany, do you know anyone who’s dad came back for them? Valerie turns to Tiffany.

dialogues.speaker: TIFFANY
dialogues.text: I don’t know anyone whose dad came back.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, me neither.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I know my dad’s coming back.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: Don’t hold your breath. They resume cutting images and tearing from magazines.  21  22

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, in fresh clothes, works quickly filling out bubbles an exam form. She finishes.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I’m finished.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Already?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yes. Jean leafs through the pages of the test booklet, nodding Surprised.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s like homework only easier.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Who gave you homework?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: My dad.  23

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Who taught you to read? We have no record of you going to school.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: My dad teaches me. You said I passed your test, so we should be able to go back home.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Yes, you’re actually quite a bit ahead of where you need to be, but school is about social skills too, not only intellectual ones.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Is my dad taking tests like this?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Yes, they’re asking him a lot of questions. Jean reels it back, sensing Tom’s concern.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want you to understand what’s happening, Tom.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: An off-trail runner reported seeing a person in Forest Park, in a part of the park where no one goes, who he thought was a minor -- hiding there, or maybe in need of help. We had to check out the report to make sure you were not in danger.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: But you can see now that I’m all right, and that I was with my father. Jean nods yes.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Do you feel safe living with your dad?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I know that the two of you share a tent. Has this ever made you uncomfortable?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: No. The tent’s warmer with two people.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Has anyone ever touched your body without your permission?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: No. My dad would not let anything bad happen to me. Jean processes this, searching for her next question.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We didn’t need to be rescued.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: That's what we’re trying to understand.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What is it you want to understand? That we could live differently from how you’re used to it being and still be fine? Tom stares at Jean.  4l 27

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will is seated in front of a computer. JAMES, the other social worker on the case arranges a key board in front o Will. James reads from the test instruction booklet.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Respond “true” or “false” to each statement. There are 435 items. If you can’t answer, wait til the next question. Complete as many as you can. (beat) Are we good? He brings the computer keyboard closer to Will.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m gonna leave you to it. James pushes the start key and leaves. TEST GIVER’S VOICE Welcome. The test will begin in 3 seconds:

dialogues.speaker: TEST GIVER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I wake up rested and peaceful most mornings

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: True.

dialogues.speaker: TEST GIVER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I enjoy reading articles on crime

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: False.

dialogues.speaker: TEST GIVER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: My daily life is full of activities that keep me interested

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: True. TEST GIVER’S VOICE My sleep is fitful and troubled. Beep. Will exceeds the limit and the computer presses on.  42

dialogues.speaker: 27A
dialogues.text: INT. SOCIAL SERVICES, JEAN’S OFFICE - DAY 42 Jean pulls out some flash cards.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: For each picture I want you to make up a story. Tom nods. Jean lays out four cards with symbolic drawings onto the table.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pick one. Tom selects a card and studies it.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: How do you read my answers? You think they’re going to mean a certain thing?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: They might be able tell us a little more about you.  28

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You could just ask.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Yes. But you may not be able to say it.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: So you go at it in a crooked way. Somehow I'll say what I can’t say? Tom writes in the test booklet.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can I see my dad, now? Just for five minutes? I know it’1l make him feel better.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You've been very patient. We’re almost there. Jean glances at her check list.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Would you say you’ve had a happy childhood?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Does your father get angry if you don’t agree with him?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: What does happen when you do something that your dad does not agree with?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We discuss it.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I wish I could have followed you around for a day, just to see how you guys operated.  43 44

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You wouldn’t have been able to. I'd lose you in five minutes. The park has 5,100 acres.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: It sounds to me like you really loved it there. But Tom, you understand that you can’t live in the park anymore? Tom looks down, averting Jean's gaze.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s not a crime to be unhoused -- many people are. But it is illegal to live in the park. Tom swallows hard, staring at the poster on the wall behi Jean. She doesn’t notice Jean’s concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tiffany and Tom are looking at Tiffany’s phone. Tiffany i explaining what instragram is and swiping through photos she’s been sent. She comes to an image of a banana slug t a friend posted from her visit to the park that day.

dialogues.speaker: TIFFANY
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Banana slug. You can eat them. You have to cook it to get the slime off. It tastes like a mushroom. The instagram discussion moves from the banana slug to Tiffany’s favorite singer and all of the followers she ha Her battery dies. Tiffany looks down at the few images Tom has collected.

dialogues.speaker: TIFFANY
dialogues.text: What are you gonna put on your board? Anything besides trees?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I’m still looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valerie comes back into the room and sits down at the tab Tiffany moves back to her seat. Tom starts to work on her dream board. Valerie is upset.

dialogues.speaker: TIFFANY
dialogues.text: How'd it go?

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: So, they couldn’t find a placement for me in that district, so I won’t be able to go to the school I wanted to.

dialogues.speaker: TIFFANY
dialogues.text: What’d Jean say?

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: She was like, “I’m really sorry, I tried really hard and blah blah blah...” Valerie looks down. Tiffany gives her a sympathetic look.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She says I’m too high risk to place and nobody wants a kid that’s my age. Tiffany tries to divert Valerie’s attention. She passes Valerie an image that she thinks she’ll like for her boar Valerie looks at the dream boards and experiences a wave frustratoin and disgust. She sweeps the boards and magazi off the table.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is bullshit. Tiffany and Tom watch as Valerie crosses the room and gra stuffed teddy bear. She sits back down at the table and p a needle out of the bear. She starts poking her finger wi the needle.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: So, what are you gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know what I’m gonna do, okay? If I knew what I was gonna do this wouldn’t be such a big deal. Tiffany shoots Tom a look. Valerie anticipates Tom’s ques and stops her from asking more.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No one is coming to get me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tiffany is concerned that Valerie is hurting herself.

dialogues.speaker: TIFFANY
dialogues.text: Did you sterilize that?

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: Of course I sterilized it. No one’s used it since the last time I used it.

dialogues.speaker: TIFFANY
dialogues.text: Did you clean your finger?

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: My dad says it’s important that if you get a cut you need to clean it out to prevent an infection from spreading.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: Your dad knows everything.  30  45 31 INT. SOCIAL SERVICES, JEAN’S OFFICE - DAY 45 Jean and James are meeting with Will for his exit evaluat

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: In finding a placement for you and Tom, we've considered what kind of support will be helpful to you two. James stares at Will’s VA file, overwhelmed.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: We want to help you meet the legal and social expectations of being a family. We don’t want you in the “system” How can we help you stay out?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: We'd like to go back to how we were living, which is a way of life that was working for us. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She has the rest of her life to conform.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Will, as much as we might want to let you go back to living as you were, we have no say over the rules and regs in the park.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: We're just not sure it’s the best thing for her. Tense silence.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Don’t let the little light go out in her. Jean and James exchange a look, jot a note.  46 47 32

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We bother no one.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Not surprisingly, you scored high on the social introversion scale, but that does not make you a dangerous person. Will takes a deep breath. James and Jean give Will an affirming smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jean leads Caroline down a maze of hallways. Finally they arrive at her office, which Jean opens with her ring of k

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom waits in the foyer. Jean approaches with her belongin and puts them down.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: All your things. Tom looks into her backpack and sees that her knife is st in her pack.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Thank you for not taking my knife. But her journal is not where she usually keeps it.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you read my journal? Jean looks uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have you been looking through it?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Yes, I did. I’m sorry. With underage people there’s a conflict between your privacy and what we need to know about you -- to ensure your well being. Tom withdraws, upset. Jean changes the subject.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I liked your notes about mushrooms.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: That doesn’t make it okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. I should have asked you, and we could have looked at it together. Jean moves on, tries to re-engage Tom.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tom, we want to try something we haven't done before. Usually, we'd put you up in a motel until we found some housing, but we found something that will be better.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: How can you say what’s good for us?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: We don’t have a lot of options, and this seemed like the best one. We found a place outside the city where you and your dad can stay until we can get you into permanent housing. I’11 be checking in with you regularly to see how you guys are doing. She cuts to the chase.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What do you think about going to a regular school?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: My dad can teach me.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: But you can have friends your own age. Wouldn’t you like that?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Sometimes I think I would, and other times I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Do you have any questions you'd like to ask me?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What’s going to happen to Tiffany and Valerie.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: We're in the process of finding them foster placements. 33  48

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will is brought in, beard groomed, wearing stiff new jean and a bright colored new coat. Tom stands up when she see him. They hug tightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will and Tom come out the front doors of the facility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom and Will are in the back seat as they drive through t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drive through the Christmas tree farms south of Portland. Will looks out the window. Tom opens her pack a gives Will his shemagh. He’s pleased to see it and stows Jean puts on the radio. After some irritating ads and bab she re-considers.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Would you like it off?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Yes. [wild lines important for this part of the ride]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car turns onto a private road where they see rows of Christmas trees and a house on a hill. EXT. MR. WALTERS’ HOUSE - DAY 52 The car pulls up and parks in a driveway where the owner, WALTERS, 50's, greets them, and they get out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, Will, Jean and Mr. Walter’s enter the cottage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom and Will look through their new home, escorted by Mr. Walters and Jean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hope this will work for you.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Walters is a generous man. Will nods. 34aA

dialogues.speaker: MR. WALTERS
dialogues.text: I’m excited we can do this. I read about you in the newspaper when they found you in the park. Jean opens the cupboards and refrigerator to show that so basic supplies have been purchased.  54 55 35

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: A few groceries to get you started. Do you like it?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It’s nice. They stand at the doorway to Tom’s new room. Neatly stack on the bed are brand new brightly colored school clothes supplies.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: We thought you could use some new clothes for school. The tour done, they file out the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group stands in front of the house saying their good byes. Mr. Walters takes a few photos on his phone.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WALTERS
dialogues.text: Tomorrow’ll be a full day. I’11 leave you two to get settled in. Mr. Walters walks back to his house. Jean gets into her c Taking stock of their new circumstances, Will is distract by the satellite dish off to the side of the cottage.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It feels good to be by ourselves again. Will opens a window and exhales out. Tom sits at the tabl

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I wish they could've just dropped us on the road and let us be. She brings him back to the here and now.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: They made me take a lot of tests. What about you?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Yes, they asked me a lot of questions.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: About us. 435 questions. (pause) It was hard not knowing how you were. Did they treat you all right? She nods.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s try to put it behind us. Tom looks around the new surroundings. Will joins her at table.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Everything's different now.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: What's different is that we’re ina kind of house that most people are comfortable with us living in. He catches her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But we can still think our own thoughts. He smiles at her. Will lifts the foil off a casserole tha was left for them, and then covers it back up.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I'll try it. INT. COTTAGE, WILL’S ROOM - NIGHT A56 Will puts the TV into the closet. INT. COTTAGE, WILL’S ROOM - NIGHT 56 Tom leans against the door of her dad’s room. She taps a little rhythm on the door jam to see if he’s awake.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You can come in. Tom enters the room and sits on the edge of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I can’t sleep.  57 37

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Not since we left the park.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: The sound of the wind in the trees used to help me fall asleep. Tom puts her face against the window, looking out. She hears

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: There’s been something on my mind.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: They said a person saw you, and that’s how they found our camp - is this true?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I saw a man, but I didn’t think he saw me.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you say something?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I was afraid to. I didn’t want to leave our camp - it was such a good one.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: We stayed there too long. a heavy sigh from Will.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Do you think you’1ll be OK here?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: We’re gonna make the best of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Tom comes into the kitchen, she finds Will peering o the window through the curtain.  38

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Morning. (pause) What are you looking at?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I’m just looking. Good morning. They eat cereal and orange juice. Tom eats hungrily. Will looks anxious.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What’s the matter?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: “To keep bright the Devil's doorknobs and scour his tubs. Better not to keep a house.” Tom sighs.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Thoreau slept inside. There’s a knock at the door. Will gets up to open the doo

dialogues.speaker: MR. WALTERS
dialogues.text: Good morning. Don’t mean to interrupt your breakfast. Will nods hello. MR. WALTERS (CONT’D) I know that you have particular ways. Will shifts his weight, trying to hide his exasperation w Mr. Walters. MR. WALTERS (CONT’D) And I don’t want to disrupt.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: What do you have planned for us today?

dialogues.speaker: MR. WALTERS
dialogues.text: I was hoping you could help with the tree work. Take the tractor and get stumps out of the south field.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I’d rather not operate heavy machinery. Is there any work with the horses that I could do? Down in the stables?  58 59 60 39

dialogues.speaker: MR. WALTERS
dialogues.text: Yes, but I’d rather you not work down there yet. Working with horses requires training. And that can happen, but for now, I need help elsewhere. Will nods, complying. MR. WALTERS (CONT’D) Do you not know how? Or is it something else? There’s silence for a moment. MR. WALTERS (CONT’D) Listen, the work that really needs doing is clearing that field. That’s how I make my money.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Okay. Tractors, trucks, armored vehicles -- whatever. I can operate them all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Footage of Will’s labor to be used throughout his stay a Walters’.) Will is given his tools in the garage. Will is working a long row of evergreens. He uses a tool shape and cut the trees evenly. The land adjacent to Walters’ has recently been logged. I the distance, Will can hear saws. He can hear the sound o helicopter overhead and looks up. (helicopter is sfx only

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KRYSS, a horse trainer does liberty training with her hor The horse runs the length of the arena and stops on a dim before the arena gate. Tom watches, peering over the arena wall. INT. COTTAGE, WILL’S ROOM - NIGHT 60 Tom walks in to check on Will, who she can hear is having nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has sat up on the edge of the bed, his head in his han as he tries to re-stabilize. Tom sits down beside him.  61 62 40 She provides a gentle distraction.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: If you could be any animal, what would you be?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: An owl.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Let’s look at the stars like we used to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom and Will lie in blankets under the night’s sky, jamme with stars. The leaves rustle. Will exhales. INT. MR. WALTERS’ HOUSE, LAUNDRY RM - DAY 62 Tom stands next to the washing machine dropping clothes i

dialogues.speaker: MR. WALTERS
dialogues.text: Different than doing laundry at your special place in the stream, I bet. Do you know how to use the machine?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We went to the laundromat sometimes, like when it was raining. Tom cuts off tags from the new bright clothes with her po knife and adds them to the load. One pair of jeans has fancy, glittery pockets, which she takes a moment to exam The way Mr. Walters is observing her makes Tom think she’ supposed to narrate what she’s doing.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These are school clothes. I’m just getting ready.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WALTERS
dialogues.text: You'll finally get to spend some time with kids your own age. That’11 change you. Tom pours some detergent into the machine. Mr. Walters ha her a small bag. MR. WALTERS (CONT’D) I gathered from the newspaper that you used to have a garden.  63 Tom looks inside the bag to find several packets of

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Thank you. Tom, interested in the article, wants to know more.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why did they want to write about us?

dialogues.speaker: MR. WALTERS
dialogues.text: A lot of people like to imagine themselves living like you guys were, but not many actually do it. 41 seeds. He fans through a pile of magazines and papers to find th article and passes it to her. She looks it over and passe the article back to him. MR. WALTERS (CONT’D) No, keep it. Your dad may want to read it.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I don’t think so. Mr. Walters shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 63 Mr. Walters stands nearby as Tom plants the seeds. She se the worms carefully aside and breaks up the clods with a trowel. Overhead, she hears a helicopter.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Lots of helicopters around here.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WALTERS
dialogues.text: Forestry mapping. Deciding where to cut next. Tom gets back to work putting the seeds in the soil. MR. WALTERS (CONT’D) This life here must seem pretty easy. Hope it’s not too boring for you.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It’s a person’s own fault if they get bored.  64 42 She works in a very focused way, finishing the row.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay. These turnips are all planted.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WALTERS
dialogues.text: I'm interested in how you were living before. Your father doesn’t seem to want to talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What would you like to know?

dialogues.speaker: MR. WALTERS
dialogues.text: I guess I’m just curious how you managed to make do with so little. What would you have done if they hadn't found you? Were you going to just keep living there?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yes. I think so. I have a question for you.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WALTERS
dialogues.text: Shoot.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: How come you’re all alone?

dialogues.speaker: MR. WALTERS
dialogues.text: I like the solitude, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You and my dad aren’t so different then.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WALTERS
dialogues.text: That could be.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Except no one bothers you about it.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WALTERS
dialogues.text: That’s true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom walks along the edge of the farm following the fence stretches along the property. She finds a rabbit randomly scampering in the middle of the gravel road. She picks it  65 43

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks into the adjoining yard. She hears a boy’s voice calling out, “Chainsaw.” ISAIAH, late teens, walks from a small half-built shed-li structure in his yard and sees that Tom has the rabbit.

dialogues.speaker: ISAIAH
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You’re welcome. Isaiah has a tool in his hand that Tom doesn’t recognize.

dialogues.speaker: ISAIAH
dialogues.text: When she sees these clippers, she takes off. He sits down on the platform, positions the rabbit like a baby in his arms and attempts to clips its nails. The rab squirms and wriggles.

dialogues.speaker: ISAIAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can you give me a hand -- hold her feet? Like this. He shows her. Tom helps restrain the rabbit.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Why do you cut its nails?

dialogues.speaker: ISAIAH
dialogues.text: So they look nice. The judges look at the nails.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What judges?

dialogues.speaker: ISAIAH
dialogues.text: For the FFA show. Tom can not figure out what he’s talking about. He can te

dialogues.speaker: ISAIAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Future Farmers of America. It’s a club for people who are interested in raising animals. It’s like 4-H.  66 44 They continue clipping.

dialogues.speaker: ISAIAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Some kids make fun of FFA, but it’s one of the best parts of school for me.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: So you're gonna be a farmer in the future?

dialogues.speaker: ISAIAH
dialogues.text: I don’t know yet. He’s curious about her.

dialogues.speaker: ISAIAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You go to school around here?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I will soon. She wonders about the half-built structure they’re sittin in.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you building? He puts down the rabbit on its mat and starts swiping thr images until he finds the one he’s looking for and shows

dialogues.speaker: ISAIAH
dialogues.text: I'd like to do something like that. He puts down the phone and physically sketches out his id

dialogues.speaker: ISAIAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sleeping loft for me. Place for her. Kitchen here. Even in a small space like this, you can have everything you need. You don’t gotta be rich to have a tiny house.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Where’re you gonna put it?

dialogues.speaker: ISAIAH
dialogues.text: Maybe Colorado.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isaiah makes chocolate milk for them. Tom holds the rabbi She looks at the fridge door which has a collection of ph of rabbits and kids with their chickens and goats. She steals a look at Isaiah stirring. He offers her a glass o the frothy milk and points to one of the photos.  67 68 69 45

dialogues.speaker: ISAIAH
dialogues.text: This is Chainsaw’s mother. INT. ISAIAH’S HOUSE, KITCHEN - DAY 67 They stand at the counter drinking the milk with the rabb between them.

dialogues.speaker: ISAIAH
dialogues.text: If you like rabbits, you should come to one of our meetings sometime, if you want. He muses.

dialogues.speaker: ISAIAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good rabbits, good kids. She notices that it’s gotten late.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I gotta go. My dad’s not going to know where I am. He hands her his phone. She doesn’t take it.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He doesn’t have one.

dialogues.speaker: ISAIAH
dialogues.text: The meetings are Wednesdays right down this road, left on Rte 119. The first place on the left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom walks briskly away, cutting across the property to ge the cottage, talking softly to herself.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Wednesdays, Rte 119, Wednesdays... Tom can see Will inside the cottage looking out. She take deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There’s an awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Where’ve you been?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I met a kid who lives down the road, and we were talking about rabbits.  46

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you tell me where you were?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: There was no time to tell you. It was just happening. Will walks to the window and looks out into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry for making you worry about me. He looks off.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If we had a phone, I could’ve called you.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: We've always been able to communicate without all that. Tom lets out a sigh and tries to be comforting.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I think we have to be able to adapt. She can see Will’s reflection in the window.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: There’s no place on this farm where we can’t be seen except for in this house. Will takes a seat at the table. Tom opens the fridge.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It’s impossible for them to be watching us all the time. Checking to see if he’s listening to her, she looks over him. He touches his beard and nods. Her own anxiety slips

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What if the kids at school think I’m strange? Beat. Will wonders what’s on her mind.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Because of the way we were living?  70 47

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: How important are their judgements?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jean unloads the van, putting a few boxes and two bicycle near the door of the cottage. She’s showing Tom the bikes when Will walks up.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: What’s all this about?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: These are things that got donated to our agency.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: We don’t need more things.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Maybe you’1l find something you can really use. What about the bikes? Jean looks at Tom.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you know how to ride? Tom shakes her head no.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sure your father can teach you. Will nods, picks up one of the boxes, and walks it into t house.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How are you feeling about this place?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I’m happy to see that you’re adjusting. Tom, take a look at these. Jean opens the flap of one of the boxes. Inside the books packed tight.  71

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Encyclopedias. Every single letter.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: World Book. Mine were Brittanica. Thank you. Will hefts another box.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Thank you for bringing these - we'll sort through them.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Ok, great. She hands Will a paper-clipped packet of papers.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is the paperwork to enroll Tom in school. Here’s the statute so you can read it and understand it. Will takes a deep breath, managing the overload of rules requirements.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Next visit, we can tackle the DMV. Will has tensed up.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: So soon?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: That’s one of the easier ones. Will forces a smile.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I‘'1ll see you guys in a couple of weeks. Jean turns toward her car. Tom and Will watch her go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom is frozen for a moment, shy about walking into a grou kids she’s never met. She takes a deep breath and heads o to the gathering. Isaiah introduces Tom to the members of the group.  72 49 The 4-H COACH wrangles the teens.

dialogues.speaker: COACH
dialogues.text: Let’s get started. She leads the group in a health check on the rabbits. Ear fur, feet are checked. Tom stands next to Isaiah. He pass the rabbit to her. He leans in to show her what to do. Tom follows along. Her fingers burrow into the soft fur. Standing there, she looks like a new member of their grou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom and Will, both in church clothes, sit in a pew. The MINISTER begins his sermon in a soothing tone.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: We're all born with a void. That’s why we're here -- to be with each other and God. Otherwise, it is too lonely. Curious, Tom steals looks at a few people in her pew. Mr. Walters is in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let me ask you this. What would you do if you had a hundred sheep and one of them wandered off? Wouldn’t you leave the ninety-nine on the hillside and go look for the one that had wandered away? I’m sure that finding him would make you happier than having the ninety-nine that never wandered off. That’s how it is with the almighty, your Father in heaven. He doesn’t want any of his sheep to stray from the flock. Matthew 18: 12-14, A collection plate is passed down their row. While the plate makes it down the pew, DEVOTIONAL DANCERS with silk flags perform to a song. Will hands Tom two singles to donate.  73 74 75 50

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After the service is over, Will follows the custom of greeting and shaking hands with church members. Tom does same. Mr. Walters greets them warmly, looking very please have Tom and Will present. As they near the exit, Tom takes brochures and literature from the membership table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom and Will ride their bikes home from church. The wind therapy is invigorating. Will lets out a yelp as he flies past Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will is making sandwiches at the counter while Tom looks through the brochures she collected from the church. She opens one and reads it to her father.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: “There are many ways to be involved -music, devotional dance, carpentry, camp, prayer group, rock ‘n roll, social media. She looks at the next brochure.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “Considering membership? Have you read the Doctrinal Statement and Core Values documents, and are you willing to live by these principles?” She steals a look at Will, curious how he responds to the questions.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “Have you read the Bylaws and are you submissive to the word of the almighty as addressed in the By- laws?” He turns to face her.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Some people get comfort from church and some people don’t.  51 He brings the sandwiches to the table and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: So that’s why we went?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Walters asked us to go. Appearances, unfortunately, count. If we dress up and show up there on Sunday, people believe certain things about us.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: That we’re more like them and that they understand us. And then they don't ask too many questions.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Why’d you shake hands with people?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: It’s the custom.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: But maybe you could make a friend with someone there?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Could be, but Church is not the first place to find a friend.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I feel like I could make a real friend at 4-H. She studies him. Will bites into his sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you growing your beard? He touches his beard and nods. Tom peels an orange. Will stirs his tea, and the clinking sound from his spoon is t only sound in the room.  76 77 52 Will peels another orange in such a way that the skin com off in one long coil. She makes a different shape out of orange peel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will and Jean are in the doorway of the cottage. Will pas a cell phone back to Jean.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: OK, we can wait on that. Tom approaches.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here's the date for the appointment with housing. Jean passes Will another packet of papers, he glances at them. Jean diverts her attention to Tom, and Will retreat into the cottage. Jean is happy to see Tom.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey there! I’ve heard you've been busy. Tom nods. Jean smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Why’s my dad upset?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: He’s struggling with some of the things he agreed to. Jean sighs.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But he needs to follow through for this to work and for you guys to stay independent. Wishing Jean could back off a little, Tom bites her tongu She sees her father walk away from the cottage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will walks past a row of horses enclosed in stalls, strok their foreheads through the bars. A HORSE OWNER enters th barn. Will, knowing that he’s not supposed to be there, h himself in the next stall, waiting to slip out.  78

dialogues.speaker: A78
dialogues.text: 79 80 53 Through the bars he sees the owner trying to get a bit in the horse’s mouth and thread the reins through the loop o the bridle. The horse is bridle shy, doesn’t want to go o the bit, and swings his head away. The rider tethers the horse and steps out to get more gea Will is face to face with the horse whose mouth metal and head gear clank against the bars. Will strokes his forehe quickly and slips out. INT. COTTAGE, WILL’S ROOM - NIGHT 78 Will sits on his bed looking out the window. (*He could a lean against the post of the porch looking out - whatever easiest for schedule)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will grooms his beard. INT. COTTAGE, TOM’S ROOM —- MORNING 79 Will wakes Tom up. When she comes to, he puts her back pa on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Pack up some of your things. Tom is confused about what’s going on. He walks out. She opens her dresser drawers, trying to de what to take. Will walks back into her room and hands her head lamp. She throws it into the pack.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t take anything you don’t need. When Will walks out, Tom looks through the colorful donat clothes and selects a shirt and hat. She tosses in a few the school supplies and buries them in the bottom of her pack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the front door, Will puts on his old coat, leaving the bright new coat he was given at social services on the ho He hands Tom her old coat. She puts her boots on, leaving sneakers. Will switches the lights on.  81

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leaving the cottage, they pass the bicycles leaning up against the side of the house. She reaches for her bike.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: No. We leave those here. They’re not ours.

dialogues.speaker: 53A
dialogues.text: 81  82 83 84 54 They hurry along the road off Mr. Walter’s property.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom and Will slip into the park from the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They arrive at what remains of their old camp. Their site has been ransacked. Will looks at the desolation marked o with yellow “No Trespassing” tape. Tom touches one of the encyclopedias strewn about, wet an bloated. The catchment is partially down and spilled over The cache buckets are open and empty. The garden is wilte and uprooted. EXT. FOREST PARK — DAY 84 A distance from their old site, Will reaches up into a ho and takes out knives in a ziplock. He extends the small scissors that fold out of the pocket knife.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: We need to cut your hair short.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: So you'll look different.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Can we wait til we get some real scissors?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Check, but keep wearing your hat.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: When are we going back?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: We're not.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I liked it there. Did you really give it a try?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: We did.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Did you?  85 55

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Our choices about how we want to live were being taken away one by one. He takes a moment.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They would have separated us eventually, if we didn’t follow their rules. Hearing her dad say this makes her feel sad. She drops th conversation. Will takes out some sandwiches from his backpack and they eat. He’s got the map of Forest Park laid out in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Won’t he notice that we’re gone?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: With luck, not til tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Where’re we going? Tom studies the map with him.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If we find a good place really deep in, do you think they’1l find us again? He’s really not sure what to do. He picks up his pack, heaves it onto his back, and they walk on. EXT. FOREST PARK, MEN’S CAMP —- DAY 85 Will and Tom approach the men’s camp, which is deserted t They walk a little further and see Larry.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: You can’t stay here with her. Now, no one can. It’s been hot since they picked you up. Services lit a fire under the rangers asses. And they've finally caught up with me.  86 87 56 Larry looks at the dozer.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: What about on the other side of the ravine? Larry shakes his head, no good.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: They're patrolling everywhere. There’s no place they don’t look for you. The bull dozer sound escalates with the crushing of Larry belongings. Will and Tom look at what Larry is watching: dozer shoves his structure down.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (shouting over the dozer) That’s all I’ve got. Tom looks at the shelter collapsing then back at Larry’s face.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've gotta find a forest where they can’t find me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom and Will walk in an industrial zone, under a bridge w the freeway towering above them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking through a chain link fence at the train yard, Tom glances at a “No Trespassing” sign, anxious that they’re going where they shouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What’re we doing here?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Looking for a train that can take us out of town.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Have you ever done this before? Tom reluctantly follows him.  88 89 57 On the tracks are more signs: Do Not Enter, Authorized personnel only, Danger. She notices how nervous Will appears, as he constantly looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move back in the car and sit crouched with their pac against the back wall. They hear the trains around them moving on different tracks. Tom’s hand grazes over some glass shards on the floor. She winces and wraps her finge her sweatshirt. Will sees what’s happened.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Let me see it. He looks at her hand, roots through his bag, and pulls ou band-aid. He wraps it around her finger. The sound of wheels squeaking on the neighboring track is piercing. Their car hasn’t moved yet.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Why’re we doing this?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: To save our money for food. The yard is quiet for a moment. Exhausted, they wait. A freight goes by on the upper track. A cop siren and bull horn break the silence. It’s an announcement directed at unauthorized people spotted on the tracks.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Please, Dad, let’s go. We shouldn’t be here.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You're right. This is an unlucky train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom stands in an outdoor waiting area at the entrance of bus station. Will comes over to Tom and gives her a ticket, and remind her of the drill.  58

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Get in line when they call the bus. Will looks around.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: When you look around like that, you look nervous. He acknowledges this and heads back toward the waiting ar Tom gets a book out of her pack. She moves back into the covered portico that stretches along the front of the station. She sits on a bench next to a WOMAN PASSENGER, o enough to be her mother, who’s reading from a tablet whil waiting.  90 91 59 Some bus departures are announced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From across the street, Valerie, the girl from social services spots Tom and heads over. They’re both surprised

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: You guys aren’t on that ranch anymore? Tom is caught out. Valerie senses she’s nervous.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I swear I’m not gonna tell anyone. Valerie looks around for Will.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you still with your dad?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: Are you guys gonna hide out in the woods again?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Silence. The bus is called. Valerie gives her a hug. Will glances back to check on Tom from the line. She heads over to the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom walks up the aisle staying close behind the woman fro the station and sits next to her on the bus. Will sits in back. A TEEN GIRL, 14, with a roller bag heads down the aisle a takes a seat a couple of rows in front of Tom. Tom glances at the man across the aisle whose phone is ma noise. A plain clothes DETECTIVE, 30s, approaches the girl. Tom leans a little closer to the woman. The detective moves i the teen traveler.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: Hey, how’s it going? He pulls a badge hanging around his neck from under his shirt. The girl looks nervous.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You traveling alone? Tom doesn’t dare look up and turns a little more toward t woman next to her.

dialogues.speaker: TEEN GIRL TRAVELER
dialogues.text: Yes. I’m 18.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: Do you have some ID?

dialogues.speaker: TEEN GIRL TRAVELER
dialogues.text: Not on me.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: Is there someone who can verify your age? The girl looks around quickly trying to think of some way out.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You gotta come with me so we can look into your situation. The detective leads her away. Tom steals a look.  92 93 60 Tom’s attention turns back to the man swiping through numerous photos. He takes selfies. Will notices all the p action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the woman is asleep, Tom gets up and heads back to w Will is sitting. Tom sits down next to her father.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: What’re you doing?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I missed you. No one’s looking at us right now. The Valerie encounter weighs heavy on her.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just before I got on the bus, I ran into the girl I met at services. She swore she won't say anything about seeing us. Hearing this, Will is anxious, but tries to rein it in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom has fallen asleep on his shoulder. He puts his arm ar her.  94 95 96 61

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus pulls into a stop, and there’s an announcement on bus PA system: “Be back on the bus in 10 minutes.”

dialogues.speaker: INT. TRUCK STOP, MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: In the snack lounge, Tom waits for Will near a blinking vending machine. Anxious that they’1l miss the bus, she looks out the glas door. She speaks through the bathroom door to Will.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Dad, the bus is gonna leave. She sees the bus pull away. Will comes out of the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: We're not getting back on. He tries to drop it, but can’t.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Was the woman on the bus asking you anything?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Nothing. She barely noticed me. She was doing things with her phone.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: And the girl at the station - she mighta seen what bus we were on. Tom looks down, nods no, avoiding him.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
