dialogues.text: This isn't the way we used to be. Will swallows hard.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: We can’t take any chances.  97 98 62

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom hangs back on the curb of the lot. From where she sta amid the din of CB radio, police scanner static, and engi noise, she can see a SECURITY GUARD doing his rounds, listening into an earbud. Will approaches an 18 wheeler where the DRIVER is standing outside of his cab.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Any chance you could give us a lift -- me and my daughter? The driver glances over at Tom, noting her age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don’t get involved with this stuff. Will quickly moves away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will approaches another truck where the DRIVER is climbin back into his cab.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Hi there.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK DRIVER 2
dialogues.text: What can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: We broke down. Any chance you could take us up the road a bit? The driver quickly takes stock of Will. He leans in, comi closer to Tom to address her directly.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK DRIVER 2
dialogues.text: Everything OK here? Tom nods. TRUCK DRIVER 2 (CONT’D) Let me talk to the kid a minute. Will takes a step back. The driver leans so that their backs are to Will. TRUCK DRIVER 2 (CONT’D) If you’re in trouble here - She spells it out in the most sincere way she can.  63

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: My dad and I just really need a ride. The driver takes a hard look at Tom, who shows no signs o distress.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK DRIVER 2
dialogues.text: I just wanna know that I’m doin’ the right thing. Hop in.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Thanks, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck is neatly organized. The driver’s sleeping area comfortable and decorated with a nature scene painted on velvet. On the driver’s bed is a little dog.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK DRIVER 2
dialogues.text: The kid can ride back there. Willie Nelson’s really friendly - ain’t you, Willie? Tom crawls to the sleeping cabin. Will settles in shotgun The driver puts on some music. Tom pets the dog who’s res its head on her. The truck pulls out. [insert shot of night road for passage of time]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck has left the highway and is climbing up a two l road in the mountains. The driver listens to the news on radio. Tom has fallen asleep. Will looks out the window. They pass a clear cut area and imposing power line towers The driver shakes his head slightly at the news.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK DRIVER 2
dialogues.text: Seeing you and your daughter reminds me of me and my daughter. I used to take her camping up here. We used to have a little place back in there. Not no more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first sign of open Wilderness is visible from the win  102 64

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK DRIVER 2
dialogues.text: We just crossed into Washington. Will registers this. TRUCK DRIVER 2 (CONT’D) Where’d you say you were headed?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Not too far from here. After a few more curves ahead, Will sees an old logging r

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're up near that next bend. Anywhere you’re able to pull over. He’s concerned.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: You sure? Here? Will nods. The driver looks for a spot to pull the truck over. Will turns around to talk to Tom.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Sweetie, we’re here. We’ve gotta get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They get out of the truck.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Thanks, much. The driver toots the horn and pulls away. Tom and Will put their packs on.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It feels a lot colder.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: It’s the altitude. Will tries to orient himself with the map. Tom adds a lay of clothes. Will does the same.  65

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will leads the way along the path. Tom is lagging behind, tired. He checks on her.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: It’s important to keep up the pace, or we'll get even colder.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I’m trying! My feet are really stinging. He roots through his pack and gets out dry socks.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: My feet are stinging, too. They sit down on a log to change socks. He guides Tom’s f under his shirt to warm them up. They put on the dry socks. Will wraps plastic bags around feet. She struggles to get her boots back on. They look around trying to get their bearings as to what direction to choose, but it all looks the same. Tom fixes on some power lines.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Do you see any power lines? The’d lead us somewhere. Wouldn’t they be connected to houses?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: They could, or they might just go up and over the mountain. Tom looks around for any other signs of where to go.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What do you think we should do?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Keep moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They resume walking.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I can’t bend my fingers.  105 66 He gestures for her to put her hands in her arm pits.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: It can happen quickly. That’s why we've got to keep moving. He puts out his hand to tug her along. He hands the last of their water to her. She takes a few and passes the bottle back to him.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You need it. It’s important to drink. Finish the rest. She takes a few more sips. In the distance, they see that the power lines just keep going and won’t lead them anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Dad, my legs are stiff. She looks to him for help.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are we looking for? Have you ever been here?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Not to this exact place. The fact that he had no specific location hits her hard.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: There’s no cabin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will sets down his pack. Adrenaline is coursing through. looks behind them and into the void ahead, trying to deci how to gamble.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I can’t feel my feet. He follows his gut about which choice gives them a better chance of surviving.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Collect branches. Tom, so stiff that she can only move slowly, collects branches and boughs. Will drags over a large fallen branc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will props one end of the branch against a stump, creatin spine for a structure. He then starts leaning branches an sticks against the spine.  106 67

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Keep adding to this. He drags another bough from a fallen tree, breaking off pieces with his foot. He shows Tom how to layer the bough over the sticks to create the debris shelter. He cuts swo fern branches with his knife and gives them to Tom to lay on.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Line the bottom. We can’t let the moisture reach us. She's adding pine needles. He tosses her some cedar. She doesn’t take it.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Use cedar for that.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What does it matter?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: It matters. Cedar keeps back the moisture. She stops moving. He wraps her in a mylar rescue blanket that’s been in his pack since the park days. They change into dry pants, adding whatever layers they c He starts to stuff debris into his coat -- his sleeves, h hat. He puts some in her hat and passes a bundle for the inside of her coat. Will gathers moss and squeezes it tightly to get some dro of water. Squeezing it takes all his strength. He drips water into Tom’s mouth. She climbs into the shelter. From inside, they cover the opening with boughs and sticks.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Still stinging?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: In the morning, we’ll have water. She doesn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tomorrow, we'll have light, we’ll find our place.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Are we going to freeze in our sleep?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: No, you'll wake up if you get too cold. We’ll get through this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shelter is illuminated by the light of morning. It is utterly still in the forest.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Clicking noise (Are you still here?) She clicks back (Yes). They crawl out of the shelter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nearby, Will gets more moist moss and they each get a few drops. They set off from the debris shelter, trudging stiffly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom is the first to spot a structure up ahead. A hundred closer, and they can see that it’s a small rustic cabin. mutters words of thanks to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 69 Tom picks up the pace. The remaining adrenalin in her bod kicks in, and she makes it to the door first. Will pries the latch off the door frame carefully using a rusted metal bar on the porch shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cabin is bare bones. Wood walls, simple furniture, wo stove. Tom sees some children’s books and games on a shel near a small couch. Tom investigates a photo on the fridge of the family who the cabin. He turns on the faucets. No water comes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will looks at the power source for the cabin. Solar batteries, long drained, encrusted with nature debris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will lights a fire in the stove. When it catches, he twir Tom into a wool blanket. Once Tom is in one blanket, Will wraps a second one around her. She’s so tightly wrapped t he props her onto the sofa. He moves her closer to the fire to warm her feet. They wa the flames.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Any better?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Tingling, throbbing. Will nods.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: That’s what happens when they warm back up.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What about you?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Mostly OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes out the three cans of soup in the kitchen cabine and heats one up. Tom can see that he’s limping a little. Will draws the curtains and lights a few candles.  70 They sit at the table eating the soup. While Will looks a map, Tom puts her hand over the flame until it’s too hot keep there. Will gets up to check the map that’s on the w Will nods,

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (tracing route with his finger) Cut across this ridge here, and if not, hitch from the road.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I wish we could just stay here for a while.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: We need provisions.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: This is kind of perfect. appreciating the remote, cosy tranquility.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe we can build ourselves a place like this.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Need to own a little land.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What about a small house that’s in a tree? We wouldn’t need land for that. We’d just need one tree. Will smiles at the rare moment when he is amused by her k logic. He keeps the optimistic planning going.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: In the Spring we can find a place where nobody will bother us. Will double checks the cabinets to see if they’ve missed food supply. He reaches to the back of a cabinet turning only condiments.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Do you miss the things we had back at the farm?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Those were never really our things.  114 71

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will looks over and sees that Tom has already fallen asle He finally looks relieved. He sits on the chair across fr her. Even though he knows she can’t hear him, he whispers her.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Sleep tight, Yellow. He blows out the candle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two remaining cans of soup are on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Which one do you want first?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Minestrone. They make a shopping list together.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: What am I missing? He passes the list to her, and she writes down a few item

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Beans. Noodles. She draws a big mushroom on the list. He smiles. Tom brings over a wool sweater for Will to layer under hi coat. He bundles up to leave. She hands him some socks. Tom gives him a hug.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dad, you’re sure I shouldn’t come with you? He puts the socks in his pocket.  72

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: No, it’s important for you to let your feet recover.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What about yours?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: They're fine.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: But you’re still limping.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Bad blister can do that. She looks at him, wondering if he’s leveling with her. Will hands Tom a debit card.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you remember the code?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yes. From the window, Tom can see Will walk away from the cabi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom spends a lonely night in the cabin. She opens the las can of soup, and cooks half of it. The wind rattles the cabin. She looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom draws the curtains, lights a candle, and settles in t wait for her dad. She gets up and opens the curtains. She looks at the map the wall of the cabin, seeing in detail the ridges and passes. She sits back in the chair. Waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom cooks the second half of the can of soup. She cleans blistered toes, wrapping them in gauze. She puts on two p of socks and her shoes.  120 73 She ties a rope to a small metal pot on one end and a colorful patterned table cloth on the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom surveys the land around the cabin, trying to see whic direction Will might be coming from. She decides on a tre that stands alone from the others and attempts to throw t metal pot over a branch so it will catch the tablecloth i the tree. After two attempts, the object flies high enoug for the cloth to get snagged in the tree. She stands back wondering how far away the colorful, wavi fabric can be seen. She shifts from foot to foot trying t keep warm. Branches creak, the wind stirs, no sign of Wil She heads back to the cabin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With no soup left, Tom stands on the counter and looks in the very back of the highest cabinet shelves to see if th might have missed something. She finds nothing edible. She opens the lower cabinets. On her hands and knees she almost crawls inside. From the way back, she pulls out a of pancake mix. There’s only a little in the box, and she taps out every drop and adds water. When she pours it int the skillet, it makes one large pancake. She eats the pancake slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom stuffs her clothes into her pack. She walks over to a pile of Will’s belongings, things he' removed from his pack when he set off across the ridge. She is hesitant to touch an envelope that is filled with documents, but peers in, decides it is important. From the things he left behind, she takes the pouch of documents, his notebook, a well worn map of Forest Park. When she looks again inside the pouch, she finds a snap s of Will, her mother, and herself as a baby. There’s anoth photo of a soldier in a hospital, one of a soldier in dre uniform, and a newspaper article.  121 122 123 74 She finds a couple of her drawings, along with poems and passages that he’s torn out from books and folded into hi sketch book. She opens a folded page taken from the Iliad

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (reading the page) Achilles went on grieving for his friend, whom he could not banish from his mind. Sleep refused to visit him. He tossed to one side and the other, thinking always of his loss...As memories crowded in on him, the warm tears poured down his cheeks. She finds a little plastic capsule with some small teeth inside. A folded paper has been inserted with the teeth.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (reading the note) Tom’s baby teeth. She looks at the objects, holding back tears. Tom lights every candle in the cabin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the front railing of the porch, she drips wax and line the candles up. She yells as loudly as she can.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: She waits. She hears the wind in the trees and the spitti of the candle flames. She goes back inside and stands at the window, looking ou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom tidies up the cabin, leaving it in good shape. She bundles back up, putting on layers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom walks deep into the woods, looking for tracks. Periodically, she stops to listen for sounds. In the distance, she hears an engine sound and quickens h pace in that direction. As she nears the edge of a ravine spot of color catches her eye. She sees her father at the bottom. She scrambles down the ravine to where he lies.  124 75

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Dad? No answer. She swallows hard.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dad? She runs over to him and shakes him gently. He’s slightly responsive, not fully conscious, but still breathing. She runs her fingers across his forehead, which is scraped an smeared with dried blood.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, Dad. She puts her hands on his face, trying to warm him. She hears the engines again, but they stop before she can figure out what direction they’re coming from.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Someone’s in these woods. I heard engines before. Tom opens her pack and layers the remaining garments over father. She puts water to his lips. She stows the water bottle inside his sweater. She opens her father’s pack an sees that he had gotten their provisions. She holds her father tight.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m getting us some help. Will nods. She walks away, backing up, afraid to turn her back on him. Tom turns to concentrate on where she should be heading, she finally breaks down. She leans against a tree wiping stinging tears from her chapped cheeks. She doesn’t know which way to walk. She turns 360, waitin for the sound again. The engines resume; she moves as fast as she can. She can hear human voices, music, and the engines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she gets closer to the sound, she sees that it’s comin from two TEENAGERS, who are horsing around on ATVs. At first, no one notices her.  76 Tom runs into their path to get their attention. One of t drivers, COLIN, 18, notices her. He’s surprised to see someone just appear, stops immediately, and cuts his engi

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I need some help.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: My dad’s hurt. I need help carrying him. Colin nods for her to get on the ATV.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I came from that direction. Tom points the way.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: You gotta hold on. She puts her arms around him. They drive into the woods a Colin’s friend follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s not clear if Will is still alive. The two teens are suddenly scared. Tom approaches Will, whispering softly.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Dad, we’re going. Will nods slightly. The two boys help Tom roll the stump off of Will and load onto the ATV. They tie Will to Colin so he won’t fall off

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom holds Will in place on the ATV. Colin drives carefull 127 EXT. DALE’S HOUSE - DAY 127 The teens pull into a gravel driveway which leads up to a cabin. The lights are on inside.  128 77

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: This is the only place anywhere near here. Tom knocks. The door is answered by DALE, a middle-age wo in Carharts.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I need some help. Dale looks over to Colin, who she recognizes as a local k

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: They friends of yours? Colin shrugs and shakes his head. Dale gestures for them bring Will in.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. DALE'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: Will is laid onto a couch. Colin and his friend back thei way to the door.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Tell me what happened.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: His leg’s hurt. He was lost for three days. He fell somehow.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: He’s gotta get to a hospital. Dale picks up her phone, poised to dial.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Can anyone from here help?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: They’1l treat him even if you don’t have money.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: He doesn’t like people to ask lots of questions.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: His leg is messed up bad. What kind of trouble are you in?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We're not in trouble. Can we just take care of it ourselves?  129 130 78 Dale steps out onto her porch, dials, and talks to someon Tom can’t hear what’s she’s saying. INT. DALE’S HOUSE - DAY 129 BLANE, 40s, a former marine corpsman, begins to triage Wi He gestures for Dale to take Tom out of the room, so he c get to work. When Blane lays his hands on Will to examine the injury, touch jolts Will into awareness. He catches Blane’s eyes, quickly turns away.

dialogues.speaker: BLANE
dialogues.text: Let me help you, brother. Will nods slightly. Blane does a procedure to check Will’ head injury, using a light to look into his eyes. EXT. DALE’S HOUSE, PORCH - DAY 130

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: What happened out there?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We got lost. Dale’s not sure what that means.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Where were you guys headed?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I don’t think we knew where we were going.  131 79

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Where is your home?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: With my dad. Dale wants to follow up with more questions, but she’s interrupted by Blane who comes into the kitchen to update them.

dialogues.speaker: BLANE
dialogues.text: He’s splinted and taped up. It’s gonna knit back, but it’1ll take time. He might’ve lost some function in his toes, but everything’s clean. Tom steals a look at Dale to see how she’s taking it all

dialogues.speaker: BLANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s drowsy from what I gave him. But try to get more food in him, when you can. Blane looks to Tom, and then hands Dale some pills.

dialogues.speaker: BLANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: For pain. Dale gives him a hug. He smiles at Tom.

dialogues.speaker: BLANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’1l come back and check on him.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Thank you. Blane leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dale is wrestling with a rolling cot. Tom helps her pull into the main room.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: I trust you, but there’s other people here that might not. If your Dad's in some kinda trouble, I need you to tell me ‘cuz folks here are not lookin’ to get mixed up in somethin’. Dale looks Tom in the eye. Tom shakes her head no.  132 133 134 135 80

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dale and Tom cover Will. Tom squeezes Will’s hand. They unfold the cot so it’s next to the sofa where Will l They make the bed. Tom gets into her cot. Will shifts position and becomes a of her next to him. He speaks softly; the words are stuck his throat.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: So sorry. She can hear that he’s choked up. He tries to say more. S spares them the agony of vocalizing his regret.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I know you are. They lie silently, neither knowing what to say. EXT. DALE’S PROPERTY - MORNING 133 She looks around the property to get a sense of where the landed. She sees several RVs set up in a long-term way -- little yards, clothes line, chimes. One RV has colored crates stacked off to the side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Dale and Tom approach the remote RV, Dale double check that Tom prefers the remote RV over the others.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: I’ve got the other RVs up the hill, one has a little yard --

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: No, this is good. My dad will like this one.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: He’s gonna need a while to recover.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We won’t be in your way here. Dale looks Tom in the eye, trying to figure out who these travelers are. Tom returns her gaze calmly and honestly. Behind them, a small Bobcat dozer, driven by ANDY, Dale’s partner, bobs down the hill transporting a mattress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are two small rooms -- a general living space and a small bedroom in the back. They set Will up in the back, propping up his leg on a pillow. Will steals a look at Da  139 82

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: (to Tom) You know where to find me.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: We won’t be here long. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: It’s not a problem. Dale smiles at them as she leaves. Tom sits on the edge of Will’s bed. From the RV’s window, observes a bird working on its nest. EXT. SUSAN’S DWELLING - DAY 139 Tom ventures over to the stacked colored crates. She watc SUSAN, the woman she had noticed before.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Have you ever seen inside a bee hive? Tom stays trained on what he’s doing -- using a smoking c to spread smoke around one of the crates.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Can I look inside? She hands Tom a veil to put over her head. Susan opens on the hives so she can look inside. She adds more smoke so can inspect the colony.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: First important thing to know -- bees don’t get aggressive unless they think their hive is being invaded. Susan allows the bees to land on her.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They're just waking up. This queen I’ve got now, this is her third year, and she’s going strong.  140 141 83

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Can I help? Susan hands her the smoker.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT 140
dialogues.text: INT. REMOTE RV, WILL’S ROOM - DAY 141 Tom checks on Will who’s looking out the window. She ente his room with two cups of tea and the jar of honey. She h a cup to Will.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Dad, there's some interesting things in this place.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Like what, for example?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: There’s a beekeeper who lives here. She catches his eye. She lifts the jar of honey.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is from the bees, from right here. When you can walk, I wanna show you. Will manages to lift his leg a little. After a second, he puts it down.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’ll take a little while, Dad. Will sighs. His mind races ahead.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: What have you told these folks about us?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Not a lot. They haven’t asked me much.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: What have they asked you?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Dale asked me if we’re in trouble. I said no. We’re not, right?  142 84 Will uses his arms to try again to lift his leg.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Do you think they called anyone?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Called who?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: People who will try to move us somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I don’t think they’d do that here.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: What makes you say that?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It's a feeling I get. Sitting on the edge of her father’s bed, she lifts the ho jar off the window sill and adds a spoonful to her tea. S dips the spoon again and turns to Will.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Want to try it?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Yes. She drizzles a long strand of honey into his cup. EXT. DALE’S CABIN - DAY 142 Tom heads over toward Dale’s. Blane is in the yard with h dog, Hector. They greet Tom warmly.

dialogues.speaker: BLANE
dialogues.text: How’s he doing?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: He’s trying to get up on the crutches.

dialogues.speaker: BLANE
dialogues.text: Takes time. Tom seizes the opportunity to talk about her dad to someo who she senses won’t use it against them.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: He wants to leave. Blane nods, understanding. He runs his hand over Hector’s head and brings him closer.  143 144 145 85

dialogues.speaker: BLANE
dialogues.text: This is Hector. He’s helped me a lot. Tom reaches out to the dog, who lets her pet him.

dialogues.speaker: BLANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You wanna take him for a couple of days? Blane puts his arms out and Hector balances on his hind l so Blane can hug him. He lets Hector jump back to all fou

dialogues.speaker: BLANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think your dad might like having him around. Let him sleep in your dad’s room. Tom looks at him curiously.

dialogues.speaker: BLANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hector can nudge him so he can come out of the dream. He does that for me. Hector buries his snout in Blane’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom brings the dog inside the RV. She lets Hector pad his into Will’s room.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Dad, that’s Hector. Blane asked if we could watch him for a few days. Hector has rested his snout on Will’s bed, looking at Wil with raised eyebrows. Will can not resist looking into th dog's eyes. He puts his hand out, and Hector licks it. Tom steals a glance at her dad relating to the dog and smiles, feeling relieved for the first time in a long whi She puts food in Hector’s bowl and heads out.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT 144
dialogues.text: EXT. DALE’S CABIN - DAY 145 Tom and Dale are at the trunk of Dale’s car unloading groceries. Tom carries one of the bags to the porch.  86 Tom has something she wants to say to Dale. Finally, she blurts it out as she pulls some folded cash from her pock

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: This is what I’ve got left. We want to stay. She shows Dale the money in her hand. Dale pushes the mon back to Tom.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: You’re welcome to stay down there til your dad gets better. If you guys were to be here for a long time, it costs something to stay on -- for propane, water, things like that.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: So is this enough?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: I don’t need to take your money right now.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We want to stay a long time. Tom tries again. Dale takes a symbolic few bills.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: I can take this as a deposit. (assuring her) I’m not gonna rent the place out from under you. Take a deep breath. You can stay.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I like living here. Tom leans into the trunk to get another grocery bag. Dale stuffing some of the cans she bought into a canvas bag. W the bag is full, she ties it shut and rolls it into a for patterned tarp.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s that for?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: I leave this out for someone who lives up in the peninsula. I haven't seen him in years, but I know he gets the food. When I come back to check, the bag’s always empty. I know he appreciates it.  146 147 87 EXT. DALE’S PROPERTY - DAY 146 Tom watches as Dale stands on a stump and wedges the bag the branches of the tree.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: It’s been the same spot for years. She pats the tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom takes mushrooms out of a grocery bag and then out of their shrink wrapped plastic container. While they cook, looks in on her father, who’s got their map laid out on h bed.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Are you hungry?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Yes. Will comes out of his room on the crutches. Tom is surpri to see him up.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You're up!

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Been practicing. He swings his leg around to sit at the table. Tom serves them each a plate of mushrooms. Will digs in, smiles at her, relishing the mushrooms. Tom is preoccupie

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I want to tell you something.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Please do.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I paid for this place, so we can stay here.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: That was the right thing to do -- pay them something for letting us be here.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I rented this place. So we can live here.  148 149 150 151 88 Will nods and keeps eating.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT 148
dialogues.text: INT. REMOTE RV, WILL’S ROOM - NIGHT 149 Hector is lying next to Will on the bed. Will pets his he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom and Will are walking near their RV. Will tries a few steps off his crutches, gingerly putting weight on his le trying to walk normally. Tom hears music from a small par in Dale's yard. Blane sees them from a distance and waves. Tom notices several neighbors carrying chairs over toward Dale's.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: c'mon?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Gonna walk around. Strengthen the leg.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Dad, please. They’re good people. She stares at him, imploring. Will feels a tug and he obliges.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT 151
dialogues.text: 152 153 89 EXT. DALE’S CABIN - DAY 152 The gathering is in process. Several people are playing music. Dale is grilling. Will manages to get his thanks out to Blane.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You look out for her. Thank you. Blane puts his hand on Will’s shoulder, acknowledging Wil gratitude. Will observes -- he can see that Tom is comfortable, and Dale is warm towards her. He stands a little apart to avo the chance encounter. Tom steals a look to check on him. While one of the neighbors is singing, Will quietly slips away. EXT. SUSAN’S DWELLING - DAY 153 Will moves quickly, despite the weakened leg. He doesn’t that Tom has followed him.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Dad, wait up. He stops and waits for her.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can I show you something? Tom beckons Will over to her hive.  154 90

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have you ever seen inside of a hive? Tom approaches the hive with the smoker. He shakes his head no. The music from the gathering has changed, and a different song wafts over the yard.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come closer. She adds a few puffs of smoke before she opens the hive. comes closer to get a look.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Close your eyes. Will does. Tom lets the bees collect on her arm.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Open. She shows her dad the arm up close. Will takes in how comfortable she is. The bees cover Tom’s arm like a long glove. She is very alive, feeling everything.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s OK, even if they get upset. A person can withstand 500 stings. She locks eyes with Will. She smiles because it feels good.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Gonna walk around. She moves to transfer the bees back to the hive.

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: EXT. DALE’S HOUSE - DAY 154 Tom has returned to the gathering. They’ve built a fire. Someone in the group is singing.  155 156 91

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will is on the front stairs of the RV listening to the distant music from the gathering, but he reacts to all so nearby. He gets up to check around the RV, then sits back down. Hector moves closer to Will and puts his head on Will’s knee.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (to Hector) She knows what she’s doing. Tom approaches the RV humming a line from the song at the shindig. She joins her dad. Tom puts her arms around him. Together, they are 50% agony; 50% hope.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I know that you have some things in your mind that I can’t understand. The Pacific Tree frogs start up their chorus and they lis together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Tom looks in Will’s room, she stops in her tracks. H few items of clothing are on the bed, along with the map, some food.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What’re you doing? Your leg isn’t even healed all the way. He finishes rolling a blanket.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It won’t heal right. I don’t want to leave. Will looks down, searching for words to explain.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Last time you almost died- He raises his eyes to look at her.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And you would have if I hadn’t found you. He looks down, thinking.  157 92

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: It won’t happen to us again. She wants him to understand; she tries again.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: The people here aren’t very different from us. Don’t you see that?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Yes. They’ve been very good to us, but we need to go back to our own way of life.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Why can’t you stay? Will shuts his eyes, wishing he had words for it. He pack food. Tom is frustrated. She watches him pack the few las things. TOM (CONT’D) The same thing that’s wrong with you is not wrong with me. She's scared that she just said that. She hears the door of the RV click. She won’t turn around look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will paces around the back of RV, Hector trails him. He c leave. Tom exits the RV and watches Will from behind a tr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom stuffs clothes and journal into her pack. From the RV she can see that Will is on the wooded path looking out f her, looking back, waiting for her. EXT. WOODS NEAR DALE’S —- DAY 158 Tom can see Will in the distance. He can’t move as quickl he once did. Tom soon overtakes him.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Are you just going to leave?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: No, I want you to come with me. Your home is with me. And mine is with you. Her tears well up.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: At least that’s the way it’s always been. She squeezes his hand. EXT. WOODS NEAR DALE’S —- DAY 159 They've been hiking for a while on an evergreen lined log path. Will stops to rest. They sit in silence. He looks up at a big tree above them lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: We'll find a good spot. Will passes Tom some of the bread he packed. He’s brought jar of honey, with the label that she’s decorated. She ta the jar, but doesn’t open it. Will reaches for the jar an drizzles some honey on the bread. She looks out into the expanse of woods. She knows why he dad loves being in the forest. A gust of wind rustles the branches. A wild hare forages, unafraid. The trees sway. He stands up ready to continue search for their new place.  160 EXT. WOODS NEAR DALE’S - LATER Will stops to look at the map and get his bearings.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: We can keep bees at our next place. 93aA

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We can find a good spot like we had in Forest Park. Don’t you want that?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We're not going to find that again. He starts to walk. Fighting heavy resistance, Tom follows father. She lags behind him. He looks back at her. Tom is distant and upset. [wildlife image]. He slows down until catches up. The leaves rustle loudly. She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dad - In the silence it becomes clear what she’s about to say.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Can you find your way back?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yes. Will’s eyes well up.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: [You taught me.]

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Tell that we’ll be in touch.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Will you check on me?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I know you would stay if you could. Will nods. Tom buries her tears in his shoulder and hugs

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I love you, Green.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I love you, Yellow. He hugs her tightly.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You know where to find me.  95 Will finds it hard to let go. Tom takes the mushroom guide out of her pack and hands it him. They stand in arm’s reach, neither able to make the first move. Will nods that it’s OK. Tom begins walking backwards, watching her dad walk away. She holds the seah until her dad becomes small in the distance. When she can longer see him, she turns forward and heads back in the direction of Dale’s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Halfway back to Dale’s, Hector meets her on the path.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: He had to go. Hector looks in the direction of Will. Tom faces forward.
